Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Stats.CollectAzureCdnLogs deadlocks on some connection failures" (#6538) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
When connecting to the FTP, Stats.CollectAzureCdnLogs, sometimes deadlocks if the connection fails.

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Jobs/blob/master/src/Stats.CollectAzureCdnLogs/Ftp/FtpRawLogClient.cs#L116

No idea what's causing this or if it's an issue with the web request APIs we're using.

Suggestion: add a cancellation token that fails the process if it takes more than a minute or so to connect.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Error message around "Unable to find project information" should be a little more specific inside VS" (#5350) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I opened a solution that I'd previously unloaded a project, and it stated the following about that project:

```
Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State
Error	NU1105	Unable to find project information for 'E:\pinvoke\src\User32\User32.csproj'. The project file may be invalid or missing targets required for restore.	Win32		1	
```

This should be more specific to the actual problem, ie "the project is unloaded".

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Non-SemVer package versions (with 4 parts)" (#7376) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
First of all, I hope this is the right place to ask such a question. If not, please feel free to close this and direct me in the right direction.

Is using a SemVer compatible version number a requirement for NuGet packages? [The only documentation I could find on this topic](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/package-versioning) talks about SemVer for package versions but it also briefly mentions the possibility of having four part versions:
> A zero in the fourth part of the version number

So, is it possible to use a version number that consists of four parts for a NuGet package? And if it is possible: Does that come with any disadvantages?

The use case is that we are currently working on a database driver and wondered whether we could include the version number of the database in the version of the library to communicate to users which version of the library is compatible with which version of the database. Since the database already has a version number that consists of three parts (like `0.3.0`), a fourth part seems to be necessary to differentiate between versions of the library for the same database version (like `0.3.0.1`, `0.3.0.2`, and so on).

(Some context: The database in question is [JanusGraph](janusgraph.org) and [we are currently discussing](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/janusgraph-dev/A55fIfpdhhA/HnPgl90ZAAAJ) about how to handle versioning for driver libraries.)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Handle signed packages SHA for post restore validation with project lock file" (#7283) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently we write down SHA of signed packages with the signature file which is different than the original SHA of the same package when it's not signed when we extract a package on disk either as part of install or restore. This will potentially break our SHA validation as part of post restore operation with repeatable build (project lock file) feature because then if a lock file already has a unsgined package SHA and later that package is repo signed by nuget.org, then any further restore validation will fail which will also fail the restore operation.

So there are multiple suggestions to solve this issue, such as:
- Write the original SHA of the package avoiding Signature file so that it's consistent with unsigned package. That way we won't need to change at multiple places but the down side is it will break existing 4.6 to 4.8 clients so we'd need to ask customers to clean their NuGet global packages folder before opting into project lock fle.

- Another option is to create a new SHAFile to keep track of original SHA of the package and use that to validate post restore. This will have the advantage to not break existing clients and not needed to clean global packages folder but the downside is that we'd need to change at multiple places starting the way we figure out if package is coming from global packages folder or not, then extraction of the package, and finally the validation.

- 3rd option is to continue with the existing code of writing SHA, but change the way we validate SHA of signed packages. So for signed packages, instead of using SHA from the assets file, we use SignUtility apis to get the original SHA and compare that wrt lock file. This will work with existing clients as well as won't need to change at too many places but the downside is to retrieve original SHA of the package specially when package is Author + Repo signed.

- more options.....

@anangaur @rrelyea @PatoBeltran @dtivel

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Differentiating Between Win10 and Nono Server" (#7375) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I am not too sure if this is the correct place, but this is not really a problem - more a question.

I am building a library (SkiaSharp) that does some font subsetting using the FONTSUB.DLL. This may be an old feature that I shouldn't use, but right now it is (I will investigate this).

As a result, SkiaSharp cannot be used on Nano Server due to this dll being unavailable. I can compile another binary that does not have this feature, but I still have to support the full set.

My question is this, if I have 2 binaries - one for Nano Server and one for Windows Server, but I can't see a way to distinguish between the two platforms. Right now I am using the `runtimes` folder in the NuGet - currently the `win7-x64` sub-dir. Is there a nanoserver variant?

The original discussion is here with missing assemblies and entry points: https://github.com/mono/SkiaSharp/issues/591#issuecomment-427605252

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Current approach to packaging x86 and x64 assemblies " (#7374) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Cannot find any documentation on how to release x86 and x64 assemblies in a single package. I 

The [supporting-multiple-target-frameworks](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/create-packages/supporting-multiple-target-frameworks):
> If you have architecture-specific assemblies, that is, separate assemblies that target ARM, x86, and x64, you must place them in a folder named **runtimes** (...)

The [nuspec](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuspec) reference does not even once mention **runtimes** location

From what I have seen after evaluation of few native packages those are stored under build\native\$(architecture) or build\native\bin\$(architecture) and consumption is supported by .targets

The [nuspec](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/reference/nuspec) reference mentions **native** location next to **build** not inside it, but this is not supported by nuget package explorer 

My current gut feeling is that I should go with **build\native\x64** and **build\native\x86** but it would be great if I could support it with something more than the gut

Thanks
J

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "A question about transitive project/package references" (#7373) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: VS UI | dotnet.exe

NuGet version: 4.7.0.5

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.1.400

VS version (if appropriate): 15.8.4

OS version: win10 v1803 (17134.286)

Worked before: Nothing is broken, I guess.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

We have a core nuget package C used by nuget package P. Then, the application A directly references C as a dotnetcore project (they both are in the same solution):

    P -> (nuget) C1
    A -> (nuget) P
    A -> (csproj) C2

C1, C2 are two different versions of C codebase. C2 has some of the code removed. However, P uses that code and this is why it still references C1 package.

However, if we run the app A and call P-related code, we get a runtime "MissingMethodException" because A directly references C2 with the code already removed.

I know this referencing scheme is weird. Is it possible to keep both `P->C1` and `A->C2` references?

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

### Sample Project

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Test Failure] Error ‘Object reference not set to an instance of an object’ occurred in the Error List after installing a package into a .NET Framework project" (#7346) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet Version: NuGet Client Dev\5.0.0.5535
VS Version: D16.0stg\28128.3000
OS Version: Build 17134.rs4_release.180410-1804 
## Detailed repro steps 
1. Launch VS.
2. New a Visual C# -> Window Classic Desktop -> ClassLibrary (.NET Framework) project.
3. Right-click on the project and click ‘Manage NuGet Packages…’.
4. Select ‘Packages.config’ as package management format in Package Manager Settings window and click 'OK'.
5. Install a package (for example, Newtonsoft.json 11.0.2).
## Excepted
The package should be installed successfully.
## Actual
There is an error occur in the Error List as below screenshot
![installed error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/40230425/46243628-f28b7700-c3c5-11e8-8938-ec589417f6f2.png)
## Note
1. The issue also repro except the .NetCore template.
2. The issue doesn’t repro on selecting ‘PackageReference’ as package management format in Package Manager Settings.
3. The issue doesn’t repro on D15.9stg + NuGet Client Release-4.9.0-Preview4\4.9.0.5536.
4. The issue doesn't repro on D16.0stg with default NuGet Client Dev\5.0.0.5495.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet restore Ambiguous project name 'project'" (#7372) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: Package Manager Console

NuGet version: 4.8.0.5385

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): 2.1.400

VS version: 15.8.1

OS version: win10 v1803 (17134.285)): 

Worked before? first time using

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Open solution

2. run 'dotnet restore' in package manager console

3. shows error: 

C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.400\NuGet.targets(114,5): error : Ambiguous project name 'project'. [C:\Users\Don\Visual Studio 2017\Projects\WTF\WTF.sln]

## Other suggested things
I have a solution which is many years old and moved from VS to VS and now resides on VS2017. I have a need for multi target to both NET35 (which is my base supported version) and NET40 (to use Task and async/wait) and so need to add .NETStandard2.0 as well to use the TFM feature in VS. Of course, that means I now need to 'dotnet restore' and fuss with nuget when I want nothing to do with it. And somehow figure out how to suppress all the standard errors.

This project port so far consists of 3 library modules (T, A, B) and one windows form application G. 
I now add references between these and they show up in a new folder PROJECTS under the NETSTANDARD dependency. Slightly new behavior, but fine. It's a reference, to a project and its dll

A -> T
B -> T
G -> T,  A, B

This fails as shown in the examples here.

If I remove the dependencies, it restores fine.

I have dozens of projects left to port and all of them have dependencies, so I can work for now by using 'dotnet restore' and then adding the dependencies back, but this isn't a long term solution.

Either I'm not doing something right or don't understand (certainly possible, maybe even probable) or else something is amiss.

Thanks.

### Verbose Logs

[dotnet.log](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2453552/dotnet.log)

### Sample Project

[WTF.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/2453557/WTF.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Building packages with project reference dependencies and those projects are also created as packages" (#7371) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have a large "foundation" solution which is comprised of ~150 projects, where about 30 of those result in nuget packages used by other applications.  Those 30 are projects like data access layers, common objects, primitives, etc.  Some of those projects depend on others in the same solution via project reference, and there are quite a few cases where both the project and the project referenced will result in nuget packages. 

When building the solution, via TFS, i have a script the current build number as the file version and informational version for assemblies, as well as in the nuspec files for each project. This script is executed before any compilation.

Given a minimal example of a Primitives (mostly interfaces( assembly and a DataRepository assembly that has a project reference on the Primitives assembly., the way I handle the nuget dependency versioning between the two packages is to use a value of SAME in the nuspec for the dependency version. The DataRepository nuspec would look like this...

```
<id>DataRepo1</id>
<more elements/>
<dependencies>
  <dependency id="Primitives" version="SAME"/>
</dependencies>
```

The versioning script script that runs during build will locate these "SAME" token values and replace them with the current build number as well. This results in the desired behavior; two packages are produced with only the files each needs and the dependencies are handled correctly.  Using a nuspec also seems to be a necessity as there are usually additional files that just packing against a csproj does not capture, and packing against a csproj has always seemed to produce inconsistent results.

This isn't a terribly complicated mechanism to accomplish what is necessary, but I think this is probably a scenario that was considered at some point during the building of NuGet.  Is there an easier way to go about this that does not require partitioning the solution (not going to happen within the next few years) or staged builds (too complicated for this)  and still gets the result?  And will this even be possible if changing to netstandard and the package reference format ?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org" (#30) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The spec to **Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org** , is ready for **review**:

|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|:----------|:------------------|
|[Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Show-source-repository-information-for-packages-on-nuget.org) | https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4941 |

**Note**: This is a short term feature to just light up the repository information on nuget.org using the `<repository>`  metadata in the nuspec. We plan to revisit the detailed functionality, in future.
